org.freezedry.persistence.keyvalue.renderers.decorators

Class StringDecorator

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.freezedry.persistence.keyvalue.renderers.decorators.StringDecorator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Copyable<Decorator>, Decorator

    public class StringDecorator
extends java.lang.Object
implements Decorator
    A Decorator that surrounds a String with quotes. For example, if the value of the String was house this method would return "house". The default decoration is to prepend the String with a quote (") and append a quote to the String. However, the prepended and appended String can be set to other values. For example, one could surround the String with parantheses or curly-braces.

    • Constructor Detail

      • StringDecorator

        public StringDecorator(java.lang.String open,
               java.lang.String close)
        Constructs a StringDecorator that sets the prepending and appending String for the decoration operation. The default decoration is to prepend the String with a quote (") and append a quote to the String. However, the prepended and appended String can be set to other values. For example, one could surround the String with parantheses or curly-braces.
        Parameters:
        open - The String that is prepended to the String being decorated.
        close - The String that is appended to the String being decorated.

      • StringDecorator

        public StringDecorator()
        Constructs a StringDecorator that sets the prepending and appending String for the decoration operation. Uses the default decoration: prepend the String with a quote (") and append a quote to the String.

      • StringDecorator

        Copy constructor
        Parameters:
        decorator - The StringDecorator to copy

    • Method Detail

      • decorate

        public java.lang.String decorate(java.lang.Object object)
        Description copied from interface: Decorator
        Converts the specified Object to a String of some format, decorates it with something, and returns it. For example, a StringDecorator takes a String and surrounds it with quotes (default behavior). So if the value of the String was house this method would return "house".
        Specified by:
        decorate in interface Decorator
        Parameters:
        object - The object to decorate
        Returns:
        The decorated object

      • isDecorated

        public boolean isDecorated(java.lang.String value)
        Description copied from interface: Decorator
        Returns true if the specified value matches the formatting used to decorate the object; false otherwise
        Specified by:
        isDecorated in interface Decorator
        Parameters:
        value - The value to test to see if it is decorated according to this class.
        Returns:
        true if the specified value matches the formatting used to decorate the object; false otherwise

      • undecorate

        public java.lang.String undecorate(java.lang.String value)
        Description copied from interface: Decorator
        Removes any decoration from the object. For example, if the value has been decorated as a String, then it removes the quotation marks (or whatever is used for the decoration of the String). If the specified value was has not been decorated in a manner consistent with the Decorator implementation, then the undecorated value return is null.
        Specified by:
        undecorate in interface Decorator
        Parameters:
        value - The value from which to remove decorations
        Returns:
        The undecorated value

      • representedClass

        public java.lang.Class<?> representedClass()
        Specified by:
        representedClass in interface Decorator
        Returns:
        The Class represented by this decorator. For example, the StringDecorator represents the String class.

      • getCopy

        public StringDecorator getCopy()
        Description copied from interface: Copyable
        Creates and returns a copy of the object x that meets the following criteria
        1. The expressions x.getCopy() != x evaluates as true
        2. The expressions x.getCopy().equals( x ) evaluates as true
        3. The expressions x.getCopy().getClass() == x.getClass() evaluates as true
        Specified by:
        getCopy in interface Copyable<Decorator>
        Returns:
        a copy of the object that meets the above criteria
